dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silence of a peaceful prairie at dusk. The sky shades of purple and orange. Short grass, rolling hills. Faint howls of coyotes in the distance. A small figure breaks the stillness. Brady walks across the plains wearing a hospital gown an cowboy boots. He has a gauze on the right side of his hea Fresh bruises around his eyes. He has run away from the hospital, dazed and tired from the long walk. He splashes through a stream of mud and horse shit. He walks towards the warm orange light of the trailer hou in the distance. INT. BRADY'S TRAILER - LIVING ROOM — MORNING Brady walks into the dim living room. The light flickers. is pale, covered in sweat and out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Dad? He stands still. No answer. INT. BRADY'S TRAILER - LILLY’S ROOM - MORNING Brady walks in and finds his little sister LILLY asleep. is 14 year old, bright, spirited and on the brink of womanhood. She has Asperger's Syndrome.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Hey Lillian... Do you know where dad is? Lilly is still half-asleep.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Ok... Go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady wakes up in bed covered in sweat. INT. BRADY’S TRAILER - BATHROOM - MORNING Brady throws up in the toilet bowl. He takes a handful of prescription medication.  3. The bloody gauze is stapled to his head. He feels the sta with his fingers, taking deep breaths and begins to pull out of his head with a hunting knife. The bloody staples drop onto the counter one by one. The fresh wound, stitched together on the back of his sha head is shocking. It looks fresh and raw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady wraps his head with plastic wrap and takes a shower awkwardly, taking care that his head doesn’t get wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady walks through the messy living room towards the fluorescent glow in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady waits as the coffee brews, spacing out. He takes a sip of the hot coffee. Another sip. His right hand twitches suddenly and starts to shake. Surprised, he quickly grabs it with his left hand, but dr the coffee cup. It shatters to the ground, coffee spillin across the cracked vinyl floor. Panicked and confused, Brady shakes his hand. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - MORNING In the blue dawn, Brady can be seen from a distance, walk from the little trailer towards the corral, where a pale horse is tied up. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - CORRAL - MORNING Brady pets GUS, his favorite horse and oldest companion. He’s a large, and magnificent, pale colored Palomino. The love between them is clear. Brady’s hand runs through Gus’s smooth coat.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: It’s good to see you Gus.  Brady notices a cut on Gus’s leg.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did you get yourself into? He checks the wound nervously.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fighting over mares again? You're lucky it wasn’t any deeper. He wraps his arms around Gus’ neck, like a child that has been away from home too long. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - FRONT YARD - MORNING Brady practices lassoing with a ranch rope. He’s rusty, missing the target repeatedly. An old pick-up pulls up. WAYNE, Brady’s father, an old-sc cowboy wearing a black denim jacket and cowboy hat, comes back drunk. Brady is not happy to see him.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here? Brady ignores him. WAYNE (CONT’D) I seen Tanner at the bar and he said you escaped. Wayne giggles as he climbs out of the pick-up.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Told you to check me out.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Doctors said you had to stay, buddy. Wayne goes up to Brady. WAYNE (CONT’D) Give me a hug. Brady backs away.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just go inside and sober up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sober up!? Let me see you rope that. Wayne points at the plastic steer dummy. WAYNE (CONT’D) Checking yourself out of the hospital like your uncle Rowdy? Annoyed, Brady ropes anyway and misses it again. Wayne starts laughing. WAYNE (CONT’D) What the hell? Can’t you rope anymore? Maybe you should’ve stayed in the hospital. Taking a deep breath. Brady ignores him. WAYNE (CONT’D) You got any chew? Brady sighs, takes his tobacco chew out of his pocket and tosses it to Wayne. Wayne puts the chew in his mouth and walks up to Brady ag WAYNE (CONT’D) Just give me a hug. Brady lets his father hug him. His expression is blank. WAYNE (CONT’D) Your hat and chaps are in the backseat. Love ya... Wayne staggers away into the house. Brady watches him for moment before going back to roping again. INT. BRADY’S TRAILER - BRADY’S ROOM - MORNING Brady puts his rodeo hat on the panelled wall. He takes h leather chaps and his spurs out of a black trash bag. He sits on the edge of the bed and cleans them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady plays cards alone at the table. Wayne, sobered up, makes three microwaved burgers (Chuck Wagons).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lil, Lilla! Hustle!! Wayne calls Lilly to come eat.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Be quiet! Lilly walks in a small voice recorder and an apple.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Ready for what?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: To eat!

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: No! Just point down! Lilly goes to sit down despite her protests.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just doesn’t no understand. And I can’t use to imagine that.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: There’s supper. You better have a bit of that Chuck Wagon.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: No way! I don’t like it! Wayne puts the soggy microwaved burger in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Just look at it. Just look at it for a second. Lilly stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: No. I’m sick of it. She pushes it away and looks over at Brady.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I can’t do anything and it’s making me all mad. Now it’s a dream and it’s not a plan as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, ok. I will make a deal with you. A bite of the Chuck Wagon or... wear a bra.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: But I don’t like that bra ever!

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Brady, get her that bra.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t try to force her to eat things she doesn’t wanna eat.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: She has to eat something and this is the only food we got.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: No way! I don’t like it! Just BS!

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You're stubborn just like your brother. Look how he ended up!

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: That’s dirty.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Big old gash on the side of his head. I told you not to go and ride that son-of-a-bitch anyway.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah well, I would’ve won the rodeo if I had got her rode. Wayne looks away for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, guys...

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Whole point is... I told you to stay home. Wayne chucks down his beer. Brady stares blankly into his burger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blackburn family grave yard - a cluster of wooden crosses. Some ancient and some new. Rusted horseshoes and weathered cowboy boots are scattere around the long grass. Brady opens the barbwire gate. A bell tied to the metal, chimes gently as he closes it behind him. Brady prays silently in front of his mother’s grave. On t wooden cross it reads: Mari Blackburn. 1963-2013. A few children’s star stickers pasted on the weathered wood. Lilly’s handy work. Brady looks up at the wooden cross.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I was tough, mom. The sound of bell chimes and long grass blowing in the wi Brady sits there and listens. INT. BRADY’S BEDROOM - DAY Brady is trying to take a nap. The wound on the side of h head looks dried up. He can hear Lilly’s laughter. Lilly walks in.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: What’s the matter Brady? She sees his wound.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh boy. Oh poor Brady.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Sit down, Lil. Brady grabs her hand and pulls her to sit down. She touch his shoulders gently while inspecting his wound.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: You won’t get hurt yourself...

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: It’s ok. Come here.  Lilly gives him a hug.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen... This time... You don’t... Lilly struggles to find her words.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t hurt boo boo?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah. She points at Brady’s wound.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: This is a head.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: It’s called ‘skull’.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah. I hurt my skull. You know what they had to do? They had to do surgery.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Surgery?! Don’t joke me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You know what they do when they do surgery?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: What do they do?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Got broke.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah. Broke my skull.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Yah. Broke my skull.  10.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: And you have to cut it with a knife. Then they put a plate in there and then they sew it up.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: But, but, but you said...

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna... not gonna what?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Bucking horse anymore.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Uh... Maybe. Lilly looks upset.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Nope! I’m not gonna die either. I’m staying alive!

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Toughest cowgirl.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Uh huh. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - NIGHT The sound of crickets and horned toads in the darkness. Brady walks down the wooden steps leading to the front do He sits on the last step, in the dreary porch light, and spits at the dirt. He is tired but he can’t sleep. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - CORRAL - DAY Brady walks towards the corral wearing his leather rodeo jacket. His eye is still bruised and he looks tired as he Wayne is trying a bay horse, while the horse’s owner, FRA is watching. Frank is an old-school rancher cowboy with r skin and a hook for a hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He’s really moving good...  Frank Wayne 11.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: How you doing Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hey Brady, how you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Shit... I’m healing up. checks out Brady’s head.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Looks pretty wicked there... rides over. He’s cocky and knows how much Brady hates watching other people ride his horses.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Frank. This idiot for a horse trainer you have ran away from the hospital four days after the surgery.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hey... Damn kid...

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to anything he says. He may not be thinking too good. The older cowboys laughs. Brady bites his tongue. Wayne Wayne Brady Wayne

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Wayne) You got him backing up pretty good? makes a kissing sound and starts backing the horse up.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Halt baba. pulls hard. The horse takes a few steps back. watches intensively.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You should lay off that horse’s face a little bit. Then he wouldn’t be putting his head there like a goose. rides around and looks at Brady patronizingly.  12.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You can tell me what to do when you're riding the son-of-a-bitch. Too bad you went to the rodeo and got all fucked up. Frank watches the father and son bickering as if he has s it many times.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Well I was doing what I...

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I’m doing your work here!

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I was doing what I fucking needed to do, aright?!

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Well, I’m doing what I need to do. Finishing something you should be doing. Brady can’t argue with that and looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady sits alone on the sofa, watching rodeo videos on TV young cowboy is riding a black bucking horse. INT. BRADY’S BEDROOM - DAY Brady is taking a nap. The door cracks open. Brady’s rodeo friends, CAT, TANNER JAMES sneak in. They’re a classic bunch of young Indian cowboys, donned in cowboy hats, denim and flannel shirts. They bend over excitedly, checking out Brady’s scar, talk in low whispers.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Holy piss!

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. He looks like Frankenstein.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: It’s fuckin’ rank.  13.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Fuck that. That’s just a scratch. James takes the drag of his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A little smoke will help. He leans forward and blows the smoke into Brady’s face. B flinches and wakes up. Everyone laughs. Brady pushes James.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here. Brady rubs his eyes, half smiling.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: You can wrap it up right?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Why? What’re you guys doing?

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Put your wranglers on man.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Yah. Let’s go get fucked up! Brady nods. The boys are already at the door.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Last of the Mohicans! Brady laughs and sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The epic landscape of the Badlands at dusk. The boys have built a campfire on one of the large rocks. They are laughing, jumping over the fire and being rowdy. The boys race up a steep hill, the half moon is bright in darkening sky above them.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Come on Brady! Brady sits back near the glow of the fire. He watches the they run up to the top.  14. Brady doesn’t follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark now and the boys are huddled around the camp fi sipping from beer bottles and talking about their rodeo injuries with great pride in the flickering glow of the f

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: That horse I got on in Fargo... Everything I heard about her was shit. But got on her and said ‘fuck it’. She was good out there for a while, until the whistle, she got real trashy and started turning there by the fence. I went over the front of her. She stepped on my head. Popped me out. Didn’t knock me out til I got to the hospital. I had a seizure and went into a coma.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Broke my thumb. Broke wrist twice. Broke my ankle. I mean I died eight times, that’s why they call me Cat. Didn't even cry or anything... Igmu! (Lakota for “Cat”)

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Got kicked in Kadoka at Rodeo Bible Camp. Went out of the back door. That wasn’t so bad. Was just kind of a stinger for a week.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Got on this great big grey mare. I was getting pretty stretched out in the end. Thank god I heard the whistle blow. Right at the end she slammed me down on the dirt. Hardest I ever been slammed before. Broke three ribs on my right side. Brady over there, told me to get on my short go horse, even though my ribs hurt like a son-of-a-bitch. Brady looks up at Tanner who is pretty drunk. TANNER (CONT’D) Ain't that right Brady? You don’t let no pain put you down. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ain’t gonna be turning out horses left and right just because your head hurts a little bit, are you? Cat looks at the boys thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I’m not, I’m drawing out of anything. I’m just taking some time off. Your brain is a little different than yo ur ribs...

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Yah I know. It’s all the same to a cowboy. Ride through the pain. Brady keeps quiet but his jaws are tense.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now don’t let this head injury go to your head. Get you scared. I know how that goes with some guys. They get scared to get on again, and they end up becoming farmers...

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Hey Brady... Cat interrupts the conversation and turns to Brady.

dialogues.speaker: CAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You seen Lane lately?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I didn’t get a chance to see him there for a while, while I was rodeoing. But they just checked him into a brand new rehab facility. Cat looks back at the fire, lost in a thought. Tanner wipes his face, looks restless after the mention o Lane.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He probably could’ve won the world if he’d had an honest chance. He was a damn good bull rider. Tanner stuffs tobacco chew into his lip.  16.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Remember when he went three for three in McCool Junction? And won it? Brady smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: That was a good night for Lane. You remember when he switched hands at Elkhorn and won the bull riding first time ever riding a bull with his right hand? Eighty four points!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Shit, one time me and Lane was coming back from a party. We was driving in Tanner's brother's car, and we was kind of talking about women. We was a little drunk and Lane looks over at me and says ‘James, you know what one thing I’ve learned in life is’ he says ‘girls, they come in with a name and they leave with a number’. James and the other boys laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kind of fucked up, but...

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Dirty dog!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yep. Lane. The laughter fades and the boys become sombre. Cat looks at the fire.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Real wild. Real good guy too. Brady looks over at Cat.

dialogues.speaker: CAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to say a prayer for him, I mean, it would be best if we said a prayer every day, you know, the guy sure could use it. But I want to go ahead and just say... Brady pulls his hood back. Tanner and James remove their hats. They bow their heads in prayer.  17.

dialogues.speaker: CAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I pray to God that he takes in all the strength from all his friends across the nation. North, south, east and west, ‘cause over this country. Cat has a thoughtful smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: CAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope he gets to ride again. Feel the wind in his back, watch it flow through the grass. Be what he wants to be, once again. Brady listens. His jaw tightens.

dialogues.speaker: CAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are him and he is us. We’re all one in this together. Mitakuye Oyasin. Brady crosses himself. Tanner and James put their hats ba on and take swigs from their beer bottles. Cat picks up his guitar and starts strumming the chords o country song he wrote called “Gambling Man” about the lif a rodeo cowboy. It used to be Brady’s favorite now it’s bittersweet for him to listen to. Brady stares into the fire, watching the eerie blue flame curl around the glowing embers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music plays as time passes. Moments of silence on the Gre Plains. A Badlands sunrise. Withering sunflowers in a fie of dry grass. Windmills. Horses at dusk. Brady wanders in the Badlands while a thunderstorm is bre in the distance, coloring the sky an unusual blend of yel and green. A significant amount of time has passed since the boys pr for their friend around the bonfire. Brady’s hair has gro back, covering up his scar. He looks thin and pale. He watches the distance lightening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady's truck speeds along the highway. Not a soul for mi  18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady is driving. He looks restless and nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady walks through glass doors of a physical rehabilitat center and stops at the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Hello, Ma’‘am. I’m here to see Lane Scott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady walks down the hallway looking for Lane’s room. INT. LANE’S ROOM - DAY Brady walks in and sees LANE sitting alone in the middle the room in his wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Hey, brother, how you doing? He walks over to Lane’s chair. The room is sparse, with a small bed in the corner, a white support pole beside it leading into the ceiling. The walls are covered in old pictures of Lane in his younger years as an up-and-coming bull rider. Lane can not speak. His bull riding accident has left him permanently paralyzed. He’s barely able to lift his left hand, using sign language to communicate. Brady gives Lane a hug, helping him to put his arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I missed you, brother. Lane slowly closes his eyes as they embrace. Brady pulls back after a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're looking good. How you feeling? He looks at Lane’s hand for an answer.  19.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Feeling good huh. It’s a pretty good place here. Lane starts to spell out each letter of the words with hi shaking left hand.

dialogues.speaker: LANE, (SIGN LANGUAGE)
dialogues.text: How’s your head?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: How’s my head...? Feeling aright... Lane starts to sign again.

dialogues.speaker: LANE, (SIGN LANGUAGE)
dialogues.text: Rub some...

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Rub some...

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...dirt in it. Brady laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And some Copenhagen too huh? Lane slowly smiles and starts to sign. Brady reads it.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: R, I, D, E... Ride. Can I ride? Am I able to ride? Lane gives him a thumb up.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not supposed to for a while. I wish I can ride, but... If I hit that plate in my head, it will cave the whole side of my head in... But... Brady looks down. INT. LANE’S ROOM - A WHILE LATER Brady and Lane watch a video of Lane on YouTube on an iPa

dialogues.speaker: LANE, (VIDEO)
dialogues.text: My name is Lane Scott. I’m eighteen years old. I’m from Kennebec, South Dakota.  20.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND, (VIDEO)
dialogues.text: Lane, he is young, but he is really good. Best bull rider coming out of South Dakota for sure.

dialogues.speaker: LANE, (VIDEO)
dialogues.text: I mean... I mean, not trying to apply anything. But, me and superman have not been seen in the same room together, so... Brady smiles and looks up at Lane. Lane smiles back. His is a lot thinner now, than the young, vibrant man in the video. His facial muscle has been damaged by the paralysi altering his looks. But Lane is smiling. He enjoys revisi these moments. The video starts to show Lane’s wild bull rides, chasing after buffaloes, being a goofy teenager. Lane stands in front of camera, wearing a cowboy hat and striped shirt.

dialogues.speaker: LANE, (VIDEO)
dialogues.text: I was about three years old when my dad introduced me to the rodeo world. There is nothing can really beat it. You get on a bull. Makes a good ride. Everybody in the stands stand up for you, yells and cheers. Your adrenaline is goin’. You just can’t stop but smiling. Lane, in his wheelchair, eyes bright, grinning happily. H has not lost his spirit.

dialogues.speaker: LANE, (VIDEO)
dialogues.text: There is nothing like strapping yourself on a 2000 pound animal and just going with it. That’s what I want to do and I want to do it for the rest of my life. I can’t imagine doing anything else. Brady's smiles slowly fades. INT. BRADY’S TRAILER - BATHROOM - THE NEXT MORNING Brady checks the now healed scar on his head. He brushes hair over to conceal it. He takes a handful of proscription pills.  21. He puts on a necktie. As he pulls the tie through the pin the fingers on his right hand suddenly grip the tie and l onto it. Brady pulls the tie out of the grip and peels his fingers open. He has gotten used to it now, he is not panicking. He shakes his hand and puts his cowboy hat on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady's truck pulls up. He is a little nervous. He checks himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Stay in here all right Lil?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Ok Brady. Lilly focuses on her recorder.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I believe my pleasure is my favorite thing to do is sing along. Brady takes tobacco chew out of his mouth and throws it o of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady sits across the table from HELENA. A Lakota woman w long braids and a strong gaze.

dialogues.speaker: HELENA
dialogues.text: Do you have a resume?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: No, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: HELENA
dialogues.text: Any job experience?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I’m a horse trainer.

dialogues.speaker: HELENA
dialogues.text: You can’t do that right now?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I would... But I can’t for a while, since I’m laid up... So...  22.

dialogues.speaker: HELENA
dialogues.text: Well, you have two options. Oglala Lakota College has a GED program. The OST TERO office has job training program for construction... Road work... Brady can’t help but interrupts her.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I'm looking for something a little more temporary than that. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...-You know, I’m... probably gonna be training horses in a few month.

dialogues.speaker: HELENA
dialogues.text: You still need something to fall back on. You can’t train horses forever. Brady looks away. Helena looks at him for another moment, then she starts writing on a posted.

dialogues.speaker: HELENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have a cousin who is the manager of Dakota Mart. His name is Robbie. They have some temporary positions. Tell him I sent you. Brady takes the posted.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Ok... Thank you. He gets up and walks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: HELENA
dialogues.text: You look like your mom. Brady stops and looks back to her.

dialogues.speaker: HELENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I used to go to high school with her. She was really awesome. Brady nods, forces a smile.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady walks across the empty parking lot towards the supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady picks up a bag of candy and looks over at the check He sees TERRI DAWN, a young woman with pink hair and dark eyes. She glances back at him. He quickly looks away. Takes a deep breath and walks towa her. He puts on a smile.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Hi Terri Dawn. Terri Dawn greets him but she is not friendly.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI DAWN
dialogues.text: Hi Brady. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Is the manager here?

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: No, why?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Never mind... A moment of awkward silence as Terri scans the items. There’s a history between them, and Terri Dawn is playing disinterested.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you worked here. Terri Dawn rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI DAWN
dialogues.text: There’s a lot that you don’t know. Brady hides his annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: So how have you been doing? Terri Dawn ignores him. Another moment passes.  24.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI DAWN
dialogues.text: I'm dating your friend Tanner, just so you know. Brady looks at her, not sure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady quickly searches his wallet. EXT. BRADY’S TRUCK - EVENING Brady drives as Lilly is singing, the sun setting behind

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Lil, I’m thinking about going to the rodeo. Do you wanna go with? Lilly looks up at Brady and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: No. Nope.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Take you to the carnival after? Get on some rides?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Carnival? Oh boy. Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The announcers voice echoes out over the rodeo grounds. Brady walks towards the glow of the flood lights above th stadium, and makes his way behind the chute. Cat and the other RODEO BOYS are surprised but happy to s him. They shake his hand and check out his scar. Brady sits back and restlessly watches everyone getting ready. He looks over at Tanner, who is getting ready for bareback ride. Tanner gives Brady the finger. Brady shake his head and looks away. The Lakota Flag Song is sung over the speakers. Brady and boys listens with their hats off in respect. Tanner climbs into the chute, onto his horse. The horse starts to buck, rattling the steel bars, showing its powe and aggression.  25. Brady and the boys steady it. The whistle blows. The gate opens. The bucking horse charges out and Tanner rides it into the arena. Brady and the boys cheer loudly for him as he rides 8 seconds. A perfect ride. The crowd cheers. The other riders soon follow. Brady watches a young rider gallop across the arena on his horse with envy. He wishes was out there too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady sits on a plastic horse on a carousel, feeling both nauseous and mortified. It feels like a bad joke. Lilly happily sits beside him, singing on her horse with hands in the air. The spinning gives Brady a bad headache. Bright lights fl by in a blur of motion, overwhelming him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud music. Neon lights. Rowdy cowboys. Brady is sitting in the corner booth, dazed from his headaches, watching Tanner, Terri Dawn and Cat talking fr across the table. Tanner is gloating about the 8 seconds ride he made today He checks on Lilly, who is sitting at the bar watching Se Street videos on her phone with James beside her. James playfully takes Lilly’s soda and she wrestles it ba Brady looks down. Having a hard time keeping his eyes ope

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Hey, wake up grandpa! Tanner slams on the table.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Falling asleep over there! Are you gonna enter for Water’s Rodeo on the 17th?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Yah. Brady nods, although this is probably unlikely.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I‘ll be ready to ride by then.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Hell ya man. It’d be good.. Terri Dawn slaps Tanners arm real hard, surprising everyo

dialogues.speaker: TERRI DAWN
dialogues.text: Tanner, quit that! He just got hurt. Come on now.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with that? His head is a long way from his heart. He won’t hurt it again.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI DAWN
dialogues.text: But he has a metal plate in his head. Brady is annoyed and embarrassed Terri is talking for him about his injury. He can defend himself.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: So?! Metal ain’t supposed to bend. He'll be fine. They both look over at Brady for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI DAWN
dialogues.text: It’s too fucking dangerous...

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just mind your own fucking business? Terri Dawn stares at Brady. Brady looks away.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI DAWN
dialogues.text: You know what? Fuck you. Terri Dawn, wounded, gets up and walks over to the bar. Tanner smirks. He gets up too.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Yah. Fuck you Brady. It’s ‘DANGEROUS’ .  27. Watching Tanner leave. Cat smiles and gives Brady a nudge

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it. Brady sighs, trying to shrug it off.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Howdy. BILL, an older cowboy, white hair beneath his hat, and a tooth pick in his cheek, sits down opposite Brady.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Are you Brady Blackburn?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Bill. Brady shakes Bill’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I heard you’re a horse trainer. I have a colt nobody can break. Will you come and look at him? Brady looks over at the bar and sees Tanner sitting next Lilly and playfully talking to her. Lilly is still laughing at her Sesame Street video.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Aren’t you way too old to be watching Sesame Street? When I was 15 I was at the bar drinking with my dad. Lilly ignores him and stares at her video.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ya thirsty? You should have some of this stuff. Tanner hands Lilly his half-drunk beer. Lilly laughs and pushes the beer away. Bill is still trying to convince Brady to train his horse Brady is barely listening.  28.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: So, what do you think? Will you come and look at him? Brady looks back to Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah, maybe, in a couple of weeks, I got my head caved in...

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (V.O)
dialogues.text: I don’t like to! He looks over at Tanner and Lilly again, his patience is wearing thin. Tanner tickles Lilly and pushes the beer bottle into her hand. She laughs and pushes it away again.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Come on! You can have a beer! Brady suddenly gets up and charges up to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is way better for you than that crap you drink... Brady grabs Tanner by the collar and shoves him HARD.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: What the fuck do you think you’re doing?! Tanner is shocked and grabs Brady by the shirt, pushing h back as others try to react.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: What the fuck man?! What you want?! Terri Dawn quickly takes Lilly's arm and they head outsid the bar. TANNER (CONT’D) I wasn’t doing nothin’! I wasn’t doing nothin’ Brady! Cat and the other cowboys pull them apart. Tanner’s cowboy hat falls to the ground. Red-faced and ruffled, he tries to compose himself.  29.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck you! I didn’t fucking do nothin’. Just being friendly that’s all. Brady glares back at him. Everyone seems shocked by Brady behavior. It has come out of nowhere and seems completely of character.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Calm down, Brady. Calm down. Cat pushes Brady aside.

dialogues.speaker: CAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tanner don’t mean nothin’ by it.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Fuck man! What the hell? Tanner fixes his jacket. Cat looks at Brady, surprised as anyone by his actions. Brady composes himself, also shocked by his own aggressio He feels the eyes of everyone on him. He looks away and quickly storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady catches up with Terri Dawn and Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Lilly, you aright?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Brady. Lilly runs to the truck, leaving Brady alone with Terri D She looks at him coldly. He’s embarrassed. A moment later, she sighs and reaches for her pocket. She pulls out a joint.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI DAWN
dialogues.text: This is what you need right now. She signals him to follow and walks away, leaving Brady standing alone in the red neon light.  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pale, bright moon is high in the sky. Coyotes howl from the distant Badlands. Lilly is playing with her recorder in the front seat. Hum softly a melody she made up. Brady and Terri Dawn share a joint in the bed of the truc Their faces lit dimly by the red neon light of the bar. B stoned. Brady leans forward to check on Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Lil, you hear them coyotes howling?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Are you cold?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: No, I’m not cold. Guess what?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: You're the greatest adventure. Terri Dawn takes a drag of the joint and coughs. She pass it to Brady.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: The problem with you boys... You don't like to get your pride hurt.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: He was making fun of Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: No, he wasn’t. You know, we don’t care how she is. She don’t care how she is. Brady leans his head back, too high to argue. A moment la

dialogues.speaker: TERRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We all love her. I think you’re embarrassed of her. Not us.  31. Brady looks over at her for a moment. He moves clumsily towards her and leans forward. She is a little surprised doesn’t move away. He kisses her on the cheek and lowers head into her lap. She maternally strokes his hair as he closes his eyes. INT. BRADY’S BEDROOM - NEXT DAY Gold star stickers are carefully applied onto Brady’s che Lilly is putting them on him while he sleeps. LOUD KNOCKS. She giggles and quickly scurries out of the room. Brady struggles to open his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady opens the door, still half asleep, covered in star stickers. MILES, a middle-aged, rough looking landlord and debt collector, with a red face and steely blue eyes, gives hi stern look as he passes. His young song, at most 12 year stands behind him with the same annoyed look on his chubb face, clearly emulating his pops.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Hey Miles. What’s goin’ on guys? They pass Brady and walk into the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles struts around the trailer like he owns it - which h does. He checks the light switches.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Looking for your dad. Brady wipes his face.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: He went to the horse sale yesterday. I haven’t seen him.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: He owes me quite a bit of money on this trailer. I need payment.  32. Brady hides his surprise.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Didn't he pay last month?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: No. It’s been four month since I seen money from him. I need somethin’. You’re gonna tell him I need some money or I gotta come and get the trailer. I’m tired of lookin’ for his ass. Miles opens the fridge and gets a beer for himself. He gi Brady another look, who is still covered in star stickers MILES (CONT’D) I like your tattoos. He opens the beers and walks out. His son following behin Brady looks down and finally sees the star stickers.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Come on Lilly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly is heating up a thin crust frozen pizza on a rotati pizza oven on the counter. While she waits, she plays wit Sesame Street music box. She cuts the pizza into smaller pieces with a pair of scissors. Brady sits on the couch, staring at Lilly’s cartoons on T He is not really watching, but lost in thoughts. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - EVENING Brady strolls across the hill. He looks down at his rundo trailer beneath the darkening sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady sits opposite the Dakota Mart MANAGER, a large man, with white hair and a sickly complexion. Brady is filling out the application.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady looks uncomfortable and out of place in the store uniform as he learns how to use the check out scanner. Hi physical presence seems diminished, as if without his cow hat, and usual attire, he is somehow smaller. Brady interacts with CUSTOMERS. He is nervous but tries t polite and do a good job. The line is long and he makes a mistake, running an item twice. One of the customer gets impatient. Brady quickly apologies. (IMPROVISE) When the line is finally cleared, Brady leans against the check out rubbing his brow. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - EVENING Bray’s truck pulls up. He climbs out like a wounded anima tired and exhausted. He walks towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady sits in bed reading a rodeo magazine. He hears the sound of a pick-up truck and looks outside. Wayne climbs out of the pickup with TODD, a local rancher They talk business as they walk towards the barn. Brady quickly gets out of the bed and heads outside. EXT. BRADY’S CORRAL - EVENING Brady walks towards the corral. He sees Wayne and Todd ar talking by his horse, Gus, who is tied to a metal poll.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: «+I just don’t know about you horse traders...

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Hey Todd. Todd turns to Brady. He’s a large man, wearing dark sunglasses to cover the heavy scarring across his face. H shakes Brady’s hand.  34.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: How you doin’ Brady? Wayne looks over at Brady nervously.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Pretty good... What’re you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Hey Todd, I haven’t talked to Brady about this. Can you just come back tomorrow and pick him up?

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Aright I can. See you Brady. Todd senses the awkwardness. He shakes their hands and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: What was that about? Brady stares at Wayne while petting Gus.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I had to sell him Gus, Brady. It takes Brady a moment to process what Wayne has said.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Sell him Gus? What do you mean you had to ‘sell him Gus’?! Gus is mine.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Gus is part of the family. I guess it’s his turn for us to make a living. Brady is furious. It’s incomprehensible to him that his father could even consider this. WAYNE (CONT’D) You want Miles to haul the trailer? Me and Lilly have no place to live?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You didn’t make any money at all?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Costs a lot to live.  35. Wayne is being dismissive, avoiding eye contact and untyi Gus’s reins.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah. Costs a lot to go to the fucking bars and casinos. He’s overstepped the line. Wayne bites back.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Brady, I don’t need your shit. It’s not like you can ride anymore, we gotta make a living somehow... Brady grabs Wayne’s shirt and pushes him against the meta gate. Wayne regains his composure calmly, staring Brady d WAYNE (CONT’D) What’re you gonna do? Fight me? Brady looks away. WAYNE (CONT’D) What’s wrong with you? Wayne walks away leaving Brady alone with Gus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady goes hunting rabbits with his pistol. Partly to let some steam. He flips the gun in his hand like a pro. The sky is cold. Brady moves through the plains. Stops. S still. A moment later, he fires. He picks up the dead rabbit from the tall grass. EXT. CAT’S TRAILER - SAME NIGHT Brady dresses the rabbit on the deck under a dim lamp. Unmoved as he pulls back the fur, revealing the bloodied, torso and breaks the thigh bones. INT. CAT’S TRAILER - NIGHT The buzzing of a tattoo gun. GABBY, Cat's girlfriend, is cooking the rabbit on the sto at the end of kitchen.  36. Needle outlining the large tattoo. Blood seeps from the l of ink. Cat is finishing up the outline of a tattoo on Brady's back. Brady welcomes the pain. It helps him to st calm and focused.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: My dad sold Gus today.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: No shit. Who did he sell it to?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Todd.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Sorry about that man.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah... Wish I can ride him one last time though... Finished the outline? Cat wipes the tattoo clean. It’s a bull rider on a buckin bull in front of a cross.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Just need to shade it huh?

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Probably wait till next time. Gabby walks over to take a look. She passes Brady a joint

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Looks really nice Brady. Who’s this supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: My buddy Lane.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: You know him?

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: He was a pretty good bull rider. Brady stares through the smoke of his joint.  37.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A lot of times, you know... you get hurt... But, you don’t think you’1l get hurt like that... I’m just... happy I came out as lucky as I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No street lights or headlights. The road ahead is dim and eerie. Brady drives. Tired. Distant. INT. BRADY’S LIVING ROOM —- DAWN Brady makes himself some coffee. He stands silhouetted in the side door of the trailer and looks out over the plains - Gus is seen as a little shape on the horizon, grazing on hill, against the early morning glow. Brady watches Gus for a moment, a calm expression in his eyes. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - DAWN Brady walks by a saddle on the fence and grabs a halter hanging next to it. He walks up the hill towards Gus, determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady slowly approaches Gus. Gus stands still, as if he were waiting for Brady. Brady gently puts the halter around Gus’ head. He pets his old friend’s face and puts his forehead again Gus'’s, praying softly.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: God, I ask you to take care of Gus on his travels. Be with him all the time and protect him. Keep him safe, God... In Jesus’s name I pray, Amen. Brady’s hands take a firm hold on Gus’s mane.  38. Brady's face, nervous but determined. Gus’s dark eyes blinks. Kicking his feet, Brady swings his body onto Gus bareback effortlessly. He steadies his nervous breathing. Petting Gus gently. Hearing the wind blowing across the prairie. The first ray of sunlight appears in the distance. Brady rides Gus, slowly walking across the open field. He kicks a little harder, Gus starts trotting. The sun is up. Bright and blinding. Gus is galloping now. Brady is back in his element. As he rides the sky seems to gets bigger, the plains vast EXT. BRADY’S CORRAL - DAY Brady loads Gus into Todd’s fancy trailer. He gives Gus a kiss on the nose and pets his neck. This is goodbye. He walks out of the trailer, Gus’s eyes stay on him as th door swings shut. He hides his sadness as he watches Todd’s pickup and the trailer drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady walks in, taking off his cowboy hat. He stops when hears Lilly’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Here’s the moon! Brady turns and heads towards the warm, reddish glow emanating from behind Lilly’s bedroom door. INT. BRADY'S TRAILER - LILLY’S ROOM - DAY Brady opens the door and sees Wayne and Lilly in her room Wayne is holding a rotating lamp that projects colorful s onto the walls. Lilly’s room is already lit by a bright p lamp. The blue stars make the space feels like a dream.  39.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Look, jump over the moon. Wayne projects the half moon from the lamp onto the wall.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Watch. He grabs Lilly’s Elmo toy and throws it over the moon projection.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Hey! My Elmo! Wayne and Brady exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Elmo! Are you ok? Look! Lilly holds Elmo up at the stars on the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at all the stars! Blue star swims across Brady’s face. Seeing how content L is and the warmth between her and Wayne, Brady he can’t h but to smile. EXT. FRANK’S HOUSE - DUSK Brady walks up to the front of Frank’s house. He whistles

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Frank! Frank walks out of the front door, still sleepy in his pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Brady? What the fuck are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You still want me to train those horses for you? EXT. FRANK’S HOUSE - CORRAL - MORNING Brady starts training a young mare named Crystal. He circ the corral with her. She is agitated. Panting, kicking di After a few rounds, he catches her and puts a halter on h  40. He then carefully puts on the saddle, firmly commanding h to stay calm when she tries to run. He holds the rein, runs in circles around her, forcing he turn with him. After a while, she is used to him. He gets on. She is nervous. He rides her around the corral, slow at first an then suddenly fast. She seems to be comfortable. Everything is going well. Brady is back doing what he lov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storm clouds are gathering. Brady rides Crystal across the hills. He takes his pistol out of his gun holder and holds it ne to Crystal’s nose, letting her smell it before shooting a times into the distance. Crystal reacts badly and tries to run. Brady holds her st lets her smell the pistol again, and shoots again until t horse is desensitized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady walks towards the horse sale, passing rows of pick- trucks and horse trailers.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey Brady! Tanner and Terri Dawn are sitting in Tanner’s pick-up. Te avoids eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Hey... what’s up guys?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Not much... What’re you doin’? It’s still awkward between Brady and Tanner after their f at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Uh... Just looking for my dad. You seen him?  41.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: He was back there in the back pin riding lose horses earlier.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Ok. Brady looks at Terri Dawn. She ignores him. Brady gives up and walks away. EXT. HORSE SALE - BACK PIN - DAY. The back pens are packed with horses for sale. Brady and Wayne are looking at a pin filled with at least fifteen horses. They swarm back and forth like fish in a net.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Victor is looking for a buckskin. What do you think of that one? Wayne whistles and seems to get the attention of a large beautiful buckskin.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Looks good. Victor doesn’t have money.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Oh, I think he came up with some recently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horse auctioneer is holding the sale with his fast talking auction chant. The round stands are filled with OLD-TIMERS. Ranchers, horseman, horse traders, mostly dressed in Wrangler jeans cowboy hats. A WOMAN is holding a raccoon on a leash. A SKINNY MAN wearing a green trucker hat is riding a hors the middle of the stands, displacing the quality of the h for the auction. Brady and Wayne are at home. They talk to each other, discussing each horse. A YOUNG COWGIRL, about 15, wearing a brown felt cowboy ha shyly greets Brady and shakes his hand in admiration.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady eats a burger, watching Wayne flirting with SUMMER, blonde bartender, who’s best days are behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne is gambling at the slot machines with Summer. Brady walks over.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You ready to go dad?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: In a little bit. It’s clear Wayne has had a few drinks too many.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Come on, we need to get to Victor’s. It’s gonna get dark.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Victor has lights. Knowing it’s useless to argue, Brady sits down to play th slot machine himself. Summer peaks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: SUMMER
dialogues.text: (to Wayne) Is that Brady?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Yah. She looks at him again over Wayne’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SUMMER
dialogues.text: Aren’t you one hell of a bronc rider? Brady stops playing, but doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: We don’t talk about that.

dialogues.speaker: SUMMER
dialogues.text: Ok... Brady goes back to playing, but his mind is elsewhere.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady leads the buckskin horse they bought at the horsesa out of an old rusty horse trailer. VICTOR, a Lakota man, with a shaven head and smudged with tattoos, stops feeding his herd of chickens and greets th Brady watches Wayne and Victor checking out the horse for moment and walks away. He wanders through Victor’s land, littered with junk cars old home appliances, almost swallowed up by sage bushes. He stops when he passes the corral and sees a beautiful b horse tied up by the fence. He walks towards the horse carefully, stopping when it st to get agitated. The horse is clearly wild. He reaches fo the horse’s nose, it pulls back violently, eyes wild, nostrils flaring. Gently and patiently, Brady reaches out and pets his nose keeps him calm. Victor walks up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: That’s Apollo.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Is he broke?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Some fucker tried to ride him and got bucked off. He quit and now it’s got all kinds of bad habits.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do with him?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Probably just keep him wild. Brady keeps his eyes on Apollo for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor’s living room is dim, covered with wall art. He is holding up a massive joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This right here, is gonna save us. Save us all.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: It may cure the Meth. Wayne sits back on the couch, chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: There is gas in here. There is oil in here. There’s cloth in here. There is rope in here. It’s the future boys. Brady lights the joint.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: So what do you think about that horse?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Looks pretty nice to me.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I want twelve fifty cash. She’s worth way more if you take her to town.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: See you boys checking out them cars out there. Looks like you need some parts. Willing to make a deal?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: ...I need a back windshield for an 82’ Camero.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What do you say I throw in that back window and I got seven hundred dollars? Brady rubs his forehead, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Seven hundread...

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Seven hundred and this bag of weed.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Dad, I know someone that’1ll pay more than that.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: But I have the cash now.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: We can take this money now, buy another horse and make some money. You always smoke my weed up. Might as well just trade with hima little bit of grass.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: If that’s what you wanna do...

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Aright, we got a deal.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Damn right. They shake hands. Brady looks down, it’s pointless to argue. EXT. FRANK’S HOUSE - CORRAL - THE NEXT DAY Brady trains Crystal by riding her and roping at the same time, getting her used to the rope. He rides her around t corral as fast as she can. The midday sun is bright. Brady struggles with the heat a headache.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Let’s take a break girl. Brady gets off Crystal. Suddenly his hand shakes and grip onto the rein.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: shit. Brady tries to peel his hand off of the rein. Crystal seems to sense Brady’s panic and begins to pull a yanking Brady along with her. Brady still can’t get his right hand to let go of the rei

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Halt Crystal. Halt! Panicking now, Crystal shakes her head, shaking Brady’s a along with it and backing away faster, until -  46. CRACK! Crystal’s body slams hard onto the wooden fence, breaking the fence in half. The pressure pulls the rein o of Brady’s hand. Out of breath and still in shock, Brady hits his hand har and quickly goes over to check on Crystal. Crystal breathes heavily and backs away from Brady. A tru has been broken.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Halt Crystal. Halt girl... Brady manages to grab Crystal’s halter and starts to pet

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry girl... Crystal slowly calms down. But Brady can’t. He looks down his hand. Concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady is working. He is in a bad mood. He is lining up women’s deodorant on the shelf. OLLIE and SAGE, two young Lakota boys walk by. Ollie is about 15, t and good-looking. Adriano is 12, awkward, wearing a white cowboy hat. Ollie notices Brady first.

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Are you Brady Blackburn? Brady turns around.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah?

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: My 1il brother is a big fan of yours. Can we take a picture? Ollie pushes Sage towards Brady. Brady smiles and shakes Adriano’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: What’s your name buddy?

dialogues.speaker: ADRIANO
dialogues.text: Adriano.  47.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Adriano. You're gonna be a bronc rider when you grow up?

dialogues.speaker: ADRIANO
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Brady puts his arm around Adriano.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You riding pony broncs yet? Adriano smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIANO
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You're gonna stick it to them when you get older huh?

dialogues.speaker: ADRIANO
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You bet. Ollie takes the photo.

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: Aright. Thank you. So... You like... work here?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: .--.I’m just trying to stay busy while I’m healing up. The two boys nod, slightly confused.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIANO
dialogues.text: Hope you get better soon. And looking forward to see you ride.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Thank you, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIANO
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You boys spur them high.  48. The boys walk away. Brady looks over. Adriano waves at hi before they disappear around the corner. Brady takes a moment and starts putting the deodorant ont the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady works the check out line. Victor puts a basket of baby product down on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Wow, Brady.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Hey, Victor. Brady starts to ring up his items. Victor looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What... You work here now?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yah. A man is gotta do what he gotta do I guess.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Hm... I don’t know. You gotta get back to riding horses and rodeo.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I know. I’m riding some gentle ones. But I just don’t have the stamina like I used to.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Apollo is waiting for you. Brady smiles, keeping his eyes on the check out screen.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: He’s a good one going to waste for sure.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I‘1l let him go for seven.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Well... I’1l see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: A horse like that needs someone like you. Brady smiles faintly and hands Victor his groceries.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, don’t give up. Victor walks away, leaving Brady at the check out line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly is reading her book out loud. Enjoying herself. Brady sits on the sofa and takes his hat off.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Lil, since you’re in high school, what do you think about taking up some sports?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Well... Do some... Shoots and hoots for... Basketball.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You wanna play basketball?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: The only sport she’s gonna play is barrel racing.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: No way! Wayne sits down next to Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I stopped by family dollar and got you a surprise. He tosses a plastic bag to Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Me? Yah! Lilly opens it and pulls out a pink bra. Her smiles drops immediately.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t think you.  50.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You don’t think so. Why the hell not? You wanna go to that rodeo with me, you gotta wear a bra. It’s public place.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: No! Brady watches the usual bickering and decides to join in.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You're in high school now, Lil. You can wear a bra.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: I don't like...

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Come on. You’re fifteen years old.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: But I don’t like fifteen anymore. I just want fourteen years old. Brady can’t help but to smile.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You can’t do a fourteen no more dear.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Yes you well! Because... It’s like a celebration coming on. But I just have... two, four, six, eight and one, three, five, seven, nine, is not a plan ever! INT. LILLY’S ROOM - DAY Lilly is sitting in her room next to her pink lamp, cutti up the bra into pieces. Brady walks in and sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Hey Lilly. Lilly picks up a speaker phone that lights up every time speaks into it and alters her voice to a strange pitch.  51.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Hey. I don’t like to wear a bra anymore. It’s all yuckey. Brady laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Lil, you know dad is just trying to watch out for you right?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Yah. I sure better tell him to watch out for the revolving door. He should just grease it.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: If you don’t wanna do something you're just not gonna do it right?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You're stubborn like your big brother. Lilly continues to cut the bra. Brady watches her and smi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady takes some money in a zip-lock bag from under his mattress. He counts it. It’s not enough to buy Apollo. He looks up and sees photos of himself riding bucking hor He looks down at his bronc saddle in the corner of the ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady walks towards the pawnshop with his saddle over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady walks in and notices a roll of saddles ready to be pawned by the door. MOE, the pawn shop employee inspects the saddle.  52.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Definitely looks like you got some wear and tear on it. A little rough there. Some custom bolts here... Uh... You definitely used it.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: It’s only been on a hundred horses or so. I won it at a pro rodeo in Cherokee, Oklahoma.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Wow. Pro rodeo huh... Saddles, we are pretty stocked up on, you know, this time of the year. Something like this I can probably offer you, four hundred bucks if that’1l help you out?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You know one of those new ones will probably run two, three thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: General rule of thumb, pawn shop offer about a quarter on the dollar, so... If it’s worth two grant, huh... Maybe just five hundred just to help you out, since you're selling it. You don’t want it back. Brady thinks and gives in.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Aright...

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Perfect, let me get some paperwork going. While Moe is typing at the computer. Brady rearrange the stirrup.

dialogues.speaker: MOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, I see a lot of cowboys coming in with their saddles. A lot of them get rid of them. You can’t rodeo forever, right? Brady looks down at the saddle, his hand holding onto the rough leather.  53. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - EVENING Brady takes the saddle from the back of the pick-up. Wayn practicing roping.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: What’re you doing with that saddle?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I was gonna pawn it.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Pawn it? For what?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: That big bay horse at Victor's. Apollo. I think he’s gonna turn out to be a good one. Brady waits. No response from Wayne. He turns and walks b to the trailer. INT. BRADY’S TRAILER - EVENING Brady walks in. Lilly is reading her book out loud.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: How's school, Lil?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: It was fun.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Oh yah?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: A sing along. I show you. Lilly starts to sing a lullaby in Spanish. Her voice is beautiful. Brady sits back and listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady is making frozen burgers. Wayne walks in and takes his hat.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I called Victor. He said you can go pick up Apollo tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: What?  54.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I sold that buckskin to a guy in Minnesota. I told Victor I’1l pay once I get the money. Brady is surprised. He stares at Wayne who is checking ou the burger on the stove. WAYNE (CONT’D) Those burgers are bad. He scoops the burger patties up and throws them in the tr opens the fridge and gets a bear. Brady still stares at h WAYNE (CONT’D) I’m going to the bar. He taps on the freezer. WAYNE (CONT’D) There’s pizza in here for Lilly. Wayne drinks his beer and leaves. Brady stands alone in the kitchen. A moment later, he smi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady leads Apollo into the trailer and shakes Victor's h

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Good luck to both of you. EXT. BRADY’S CORRAL - DAY Brady uses a rope to lasso Apollo’s right hind leg. Apoll agitated, kicking dirt and resisting by the fence. Once the rope is around Apollo's heel, Brady ties the oth end to a poll. He then grabs the saddle. Apollo starts th struggle. He is tough and powerful, but his halter and th rope holds him in place. The wooden fence shakes violentl he thrusts his body to break free. Brady puts the saddle on him and lets him lose. Apollo st bucking immediately. Brady isn’t afraid, he welcomes it b running at Apollo, getting him agitated and bucking. Brad makes all kinds of loud and aggressive noises, waving his and hands. Apollo bucks and runs. It’s like a violent dan Finally, Apollo seems to calm down a little.  55. Brady starts to flap the stirrup against Apollo’s body. Apollo starts to buck again. They go at this for a while until Apollo is desensitized. Brady grabs the rein and Apollo’s mane. He turns Apollo w keeping one of his feet in the stirrup. When he feels comfortable, he swings around and gets on Apollo. Apollo's body freezes. Brady starts to kick and signals Apollo to move. Suddenly Apollo starts to run real fast a bucking at the same time. Brady hangs on tight. Instead o trying to calm Apollo down, Brady keeps making loud noise kicking and getting Apollo to buck. Until finally, Apollo slows down and starts to run normally. They run around the corral until both are exhausted. Brady gets off Apollo and pets him. He backs away holding rein, keeping his eyes on Apollo. Brady gets on one knee, lower himself to Apollo.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Step forward. Come on, buddy, just one step. Slowly, Apollo takes a step.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good boy. That’s it. Brady gently pets Apollo’s nose.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had a big ol’ horse like you named Gus. Now that he is gone, think you can take care of me? Apollo's eyes are a light shade of amber. Brady smiles. Music starts. Time is passing -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music continues. Brady's truck pulls up to a secret spot in the Badlands called “Wolf Camp”. Brady and Lilly walk out of the truck towards the edge of Badlands. It’s the most breathtaking view at sunset.  56. The Badlands stretches towards the horizon. The sky is a beautiful shade of purple, orange and blue. Brady and Lilly are sitting at the edge.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Good night sun! See you in the morning! Brady watches the last ray of sun disappearing.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You know Lil... I’m sorry I haven't been around that much... Busy rodeoing and all...

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: I know. You just... Long time ago. It’s good. You’re fine. I’m good. Now I’m just feel sorry too.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: .+.-Do you miss mom?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: Yah... I’m sure it’s a good adventure again. Brady looks back at the horizon. The sun has disappeared the Badlands wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music continues - The sunrise. Brady walks around holding a halter, calling out for Apol

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Come on Apollo! Come on buddy! He stops when he notices Apollo on a hill grazing. He whistles loudly. Apollo perks its head up, sees Brady, and runs down the h towards him. He stops right in front of Brady. Brady is riding Apollo across the plains. The purplish Badlands passing them as he gallops.  57. EXT. BILL’S CORRAL - EVENING Music continues - Brady trains Bill’s horse - a brown Arabian colt that’s n been rode before. Bill is the silver-haired cowboy who as him for help at the bar. The young horse runs around the corral, avoiding Brady an Bill at first, slipping, falling to the ground, getting u runs again, panting, agitated. Brady is calm. Like a fish to water, Brady seems to understand every movement of the horse, as if they are lo in some kind of telepathic dance routine. Bill is speechless when Brady manages to get on the colt bareback in no time. INT. BRADY’S TRAILER - LIVING ROOM - TIME PASSING Music continues - Brady and Wayne are sitting at the table, sharing a joint looking through horse papers.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Heard about Superbars. He was a good old horse back in 60s or so. Wish he was buckskin. Wayne takes a galp of his beer.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Every body gets color blind in the horse world.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You can’t ride the color, you can’t ride the papers.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: No. The father and son continue to share their knowledge and for horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The harvest moon is bright in the sky. The edge of the Badlands is visible in the dark.  58. Brady walks around by himself. Music ends. End of time pass montage. EXT. BRADY’S CORRAL - MORNING Brady rides hard, galloping across the prairie. He slows down, puling on the reins as the sun glares down above him. He rubs his brow, suddenly feeling faint. He lurches forw and vomits. He loses control, jumping from Apollo and staggering before falling collapses onto the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady wakes up in the dim hospital room. He is lying in b wearing a blue gown and oxygen tubes in his nose. He leans forward, pulling them off and ripping off the bl pressure aneroid on his arm. INT. HOSPITAL - DOCTOR’S OFFICE - DAY Brady sits opposite the DOCTOR at her desk, Wayne sitting a chair in the corner. The doctor shows him the x-rays highlighting the severity of his injury. Wayne sits by Br slouched in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What’s going on with your hand is called a partial complex seizure. It’s not uncommon with head injuries like yours. Brady wipes his forehead. Wayne shifts in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your brain is sending these impulses so fast to your hand that your hand cant keep up. This could explain your dizziness and it’s probably why you fainted. Brady looks down.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Resting is very important Brady... Your Dad says you haven’t been resting at all? Is that right?  59.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I told him to rest. He never listens though. It’s lucky he didn’t hurt his head.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: If you don’t stop your seizures are going to get worse. No more riding, no more rodeos. You cant afford another head injury on top of the one you already have. OK? Brady leans back in his chair. Dejected.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. PICK-UP ON HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: Wayne is driving. He looks over at Brady.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Well, Brady, sometimes we gotta play the cards we’re dealt. Sometimes... I guess... dreams aren’t meant to be. Brady stays quiet. Wayne looks over at him again. WAYNE (CONT’D) You know, I’m your dad. You can talk to me. Brady continues to keep quiet. WAYNE (CONT’D) Too bad your mom ain’t here. You and her can be stubborn together. Brady stares at the disappearing lights outside the windo His face expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady stands alone outside the store. The sun has set and people are climbing into their cars to head home. He spit chew into an empty soda bottle and looks up. He notices a young man riding a horse on the side of the highway towards the parking lot. JOHNNY, a young Lakota teenager, climbs from the horse an ties him to a pole.  60. He walks passed Brady and they nod to each other in acknowledgement before Johnny goes into the store. Brady walks towards the horse. He lets the horse smell hi hand and pets him. The horse seems out of place in this urban environment of traffic and concrete. Brady sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady cleans up the food prep room. Washing blood from carving knives. He mops the floor in the dim hallway. He takes off his store uniform, changes into his cowboy outfit and puts his cowboy hat on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A collection of Brady’s rodeo belt buckles sits on the drawer. Prescription bottles, bullets, tobacco chews and grey colored bible on the night stand. Brady watches videos of himself riding at various rodeos. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - THE NEXT DAY

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Stay back in your saddle. Brady is training James to ride saddle bronc on a tall training barrel that moves like a bucking horse, while Ca operates it with a lever handle. Brady is holding the rope and shows James how to keep equ pressure, how to squeeze the swells.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're gonna kick. See how that works? Keep the slack out of your rein. Brady and James's hand grip the rope as the large barrel creeks back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ready? No slack! Pressure! Where’s the pressure?  61. James, his face flushed and dotted with sweat, leans back his arm in the air, rock back and forth in an imaginary r

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like that! Perfect. Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: So after that I throw my shoulder back?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yes, to get rid of the slack in your rein then up in the air and to your left. The younger James dotes on his every word. Acting out the action as Brady speaks. Cat lifts the lever handle, as James ricks back and forth throwing his legs forward, blowing air from his cheeks as Brady gives instructions.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ride like it’s gonna be the last horse you ever get on. Because any bronc could be the last one. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - LATER Brady climbs up onto the training barrel.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Big ol’ shaggy bronc. Brady laughs as he arranges the rope.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Ok, I’m gonna feel the jump. Go ahead. Cat pulls the lever as Brady finds the right length for h rope. He’s satisfied and gives Cat the nod to start pushi Brady rocks back and forth, kicking his legs out, and tur his rigid body in synchronization with the rocking of the barrel. He’s serious and focused.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See how I go back and across? Cat smiles as he pushes down on the lever. Its good to se Brady up there again, even if only on a practice barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lift!
See? Give him some rein. Hold hima second then beat him back to the ground! Fast feet!

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: Be like water my friend. The intensity on Brady’s face lifts for a second. He’s already out of breath. He leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: James, you wanna try? As Brady leans forward he finds he can’t let His hand is gripping around the rope tightly control it. Trying hard not to make anything of the other boys, he struggles to peel open

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: You aright?

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m fine. Brady pulls his hand free and lowers himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
